msIdentifier.altName: Bibl. Ms. H. L. a) fol. 13

msItem.author: Vegetius Renatus, Flavius
msItem.title: Epithoma rei militaris
msItem.incipit: Primus liber electionem edocet iuniorum ex quibus
msItem.explicit: in his frequentior usus invenit quam vetus doctrina monstraverat.
msItem.rubric: Flavii Vegetii Renati viri illustris liber quartus et ultimus explicit.

bibl.title: P. Flavii Vegetii Renati Epitoma rei militaris

imprint.biblScope: pp. xv-xvi (Medeltidshandskrift 8 is F* erroneously dated to late 11th century).

collation.p: 5 quires: I: 10 (ff. 1-10), II: 10 (ff. 11-20), III: 8 (ff. 21-28), IV: 10 (ff. 29-38) V: 2 (ff. 39-40). One senion is missing after f. 28, corresponding to book 3: 6,7-8,1 and book 3: 11,6-book 4: prol. 6. Collation is uncertain since the manuscript has been rebound. Quire signatures in upper margin of all leaves. Catchwords at ff. 20v, 28v, 38v.

layout.p: One column; 33 written lines; pricked in outer margin, dry point ruling; written space: 185 x 110 mm.

handDesc.p: One hand; humanistic cursive book script. Rubricated.

binding.p: Limp paper binding, Sweden 18th century. Size: 285 x 178 x 15 mm.

Limp paper binding of red, blue and yellow placard marble. Lower fore-edge corner of the upper cover lost. Back missing. Trimmed edges. Single plain flyleaves and pastedowns of paper. On front pastedown two former shelfmarks (cfr. above) and further down a note in the hand of Gustaf Sommelius, librarian at Lund University Library 1767-99, on the contents: Flavius Vegetius. All along sewing on two parchment tapes. The manuscript is kept in a archival paper folder.

foliation.p: Foliated in pencil by modern cataloguer in upper right corner.

additions.p: Slip inserted before f. i with a note on the contents of the manuscript and an erroneous dating.

condition.p: Several leaves (ff. 1, 2, 3, 11, 29) are badly damaged after having been treated with some kind of chemical substance probably in order to enhance legibility.

acquisition.p: The manuscript was supposedly given to the University Library by professor Andreas Riddermarck (1651-1707). His name appears in the lower margin of f. 1r.

source.p: Catalogued and encoded by Eva Nilsson Nylander in June of 2001.
